title: Sint Maarten (Dutch part) - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: On 7 December 2020, in Philipsburg, Sint Maarten, labour groups and unions protested outside the Government Building to ask attention to a number of labour issues on the island, such as unjust treatment by management, unlawful dismissals and reduced salaries. [size=no report]

On 9 October 2020, in Maho Reef, Sint Maarten, around 200 protesters gathered on the Maho Beach to protest against plans to create a dolphinarium and a sea aquarium with a breakwater at a hotel. The protesters say that a breakwater at the proposed location would have detrimental effects on local ecosystems which include endangered species of coral. [size=around 200]
The Daily Herald Sint Maarten; Caribisch Netwerk NTR; Antiliaans Dagblad

On 15 September 2020, in Cole Bay, Sint Maarten, hundreds of residents participated in a protest taking place simultaneously on the French and Dutch part of the island. Protesters marched from both sides to the border checkpoint. The march, organized by Soualiga United, was a protest against the border closure between the two parts of the island which was imposed by the French side to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. The march was successful, and the border was opened. [size=hundreds]
On 1 July 2020, near Simpson Bay, airport workers protested and blocked the runway of the airport. They demanded that their promised outstanding back-pay would be paid. [size=no report]

On 23 June 2020, in Philipsburg, health workers of the WIHCWUA union marched in protest for the second day in a row to protest against the CFO of the Sint Maarten Medical Center who they accuse of intimidating and bullying employees. [size=no report]

On 22 June 2020, in Philipsburg, a march was organized by the Windward Islands Chamber of Labour Unions and the unions attached to it. People from various labour groups marched in protest against worker discrimination and to call for respect for human rights. [size=no report]
Around 12 June 2020 (as reported), in Philipsburg, dozens of people gathered to protest in solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement. [size=dozens]
On 28 May 2020, in Philipsburg, teachers protested in front of the government building over proposed budget cuts to be implemented. [size=no report]
On 28 May 2020, in Philipsburg, scores of civil servants protested at the Government Administration Building to protest against a cut in vacation pay proposed by the government. [size=scores]
On 22 April 2020, in St. Peters, Sint Maarten, police officers hit men who were in violation of the coronavirus curfew with their baton.
On 30 March 2020, throughout Sint Maarten a curfew was imposed to stop the spread of coronavirus.
On 17 March 2020, Sint Maarten closed its borders and banned all incoming flights to prevent the spread of coronavirus.
Health Workers (Sint Maarten); Labour Group (Sint Maarten)

On 06 December 2019 in Philipsburg, firefighters and ambulance personnel staged a protest at the Salt Pickers roundabout, blocking traffic and sounding the sirens from their emergency vehicles. They then went to the Government Administration Building to discuss the issue of relocation of staff. [size=no report]

On September 24, 2019, in Philipsburg, the Council of Ministers has dissolved Parliament and called for new elections, which would make it the ninth parliament in the country_ nine years of independence.
On 29 August 2018, in Philipsburg, Sint Maarten, about 250 people protested against the Netherlands, which they say interferes too much in internal affairs of the island. [size=about 250]
